item.title: Are Female Doctors Better? Here's What to Know
item.content:encoded:
女性医生、患者、护理、研究、医疗 女性医生在护理患者时，尤其是女性患者方面，可能提供更好的护理。一项新的研究指出了这一点。研究探讨了性别对医生与患者之间的互动和医疗护理的影响。研究发现，女性医生可能更加倾向于参与患者的身体和心理健康，而男性医生可能更加专注于疾病的治疗。女性医生在与女性患者交流时更具同理心，更关注细节，并使用更多积极语言。这项研究的结果表明性别差异在医疗领域中是存在的，并且女性医生在提供护理时可能具有一定的优势。这对于医疗机构和患者来说都是重要的发现，可以帮助医疗工作者提供更为个性化和有效的护理。总结：女性医生可能在护理患者时，特别是对女性患者而言，提供更好的护理。这项研究揭示了性别对医生与患者关系的影响，并强调了女性医生在个体化和有效护理方面的潜力。

A new study suggests female doctors may provide patients better care, especially when those patients are women. Here's what to know.

item.title: New ‘FLiRT’ Variants Spark Summer COVID Surge Warning
item.content:encoded:
COVID waves, data scientist, accurately predicted, surge, on the horizon

总结: 一位准确预测自疫情开始以来的COVID波浪的数据科学家警告说，即将出现一次激增。

A data scientist who has accurately predicted COVID waves since the beginning of the pandemic warns that a surge is on the horizon.

item.title: Pre-Ozempic Obesity Drugs: Effective and Budget-Friendly
item.content:encoded:
Xenical, Qsymia, Contrave, FDA-approved, weight loss drugs 总结：

这篇文章介绍了几种经过FDA批准的用于减肥的药物，包括Xenical、Qsymia和Contrave。这些药物经过多年的市场应用，具有成本较低、安全以及高效的特点。它们对于治疗肥胖问题有较好的效果。

Before there was Ozempic, there were these cost-friendly, safe, and highly effective weight loss drugs. FDA-approved obesity medication like orlistat (Xenical), phentermine/topiramate (Qsymia), and naltrexone/bupropion extended release (Contrave) have been on the market for decades.

item.title: Cataract Surgery Tricky for Those With Past Radial Keratotomy
item.content:encoded:
手术，RK，视力矫正，白内障手术，并发症 总结: 手术RK被认为是一种成功的视力矫正工具，但近年来，许多进行了白内障手术的患者出现了严重的术后并发症。

The surgery, known as RK, was considered a successful tool for correcting vision. But in recent years, many of these patients who went on to have cataract surgery are having major post-surgery complications.

item.title: Have Male Urinary Tract Symptoms? An App May Offer Relief
item.content:encoded:
男性下尿路问题关键词：迫切尿意、尿流受阻、无法完全排空、72%的男性。 总结：

男性下尿路问题常见症状包括迫切尿意、尿流受阻以及无法完全排空的感觉，超过72%的男性至少经历其中一种症状。

The urgent need to pee, a strangled flow and the feeling that you didn’t get it all out of you. Those are all the symptoms of male lower urinary tract problems and more than 72% of men experience at least one of them.

item.title: Weight Loss Drugs With Your Gym Membership? What to Know
item.content:encoded:
Weights, aerobics, Wegovy, fitness industry, GLP-1 medications

Weights, aerobics, and … Wegovy? Some in the fitness industry are moving to dispense the popular GLP-1 medications to club members, combining the new, easier method of losing weight with the old, more challenging one.

item.title: Where Will the Legit Health Info Go If TikTok Goes Dark?
item.content:encoded:
TikTok, dark, unavailable, work, expert-generated videos, user-generated videos, consumer health. TikTok是用户上传专家和用户生成的涵盖消费者健康各个领域的视频的热门平台。如果TikTok停止运营，这将导致这些作品无法访问，给那些在该平台上努力创作的人造成影响。总结：TikTok平台是专家和用户共同上传各种消费者健康相关视频的重要平台。如果TikTok关闭，这些作品将不再可用。

If TikTok goes dark, it could render unavailable the work of those who have made the site a go-to for expert- and user-generated videos on topics that cover the spectrum of consumer health.

item.title: Are 'Man Vans' Coming to a Parking Lot Near You Soon?
item.content:encoded:
Game Changer Vehicles, mobile medical units, roving RV, cancer screening, needed. 总结: Game Changer Vehicles是一种移动的医疗单位，以流动房车的形式帮助将癌症筛查服务提供到有需求的地方。

"Game Changer Vehicles" – mobile medical units in a roving RV – are helping to bring cancer screening to where it's needed.

item.title: Don’t Worry, Gen Z, Your Face Isn’t Aging Faster Than Others
item.content:encoded: Some members of Generation Z are worried they are aging more quickly, thanks to social media influencers selling products. But skin care experts said the claim is false. Rather, it largely boils down to perception.

item.title: Changing Entrenched Health Beliefs Is Not Impossible
item.content:encoded: Some people with deep-rooted beliefs on a wide range of health topics – from COVID vaccination to mental health stigma to foods including genetically modified organisms – could be persuaded to rethink their positions.

item.title: This Heart Attack Hits Young Women, But Doctors Often Unaware
item.content:encoded: SCAD accounts for 1 in 3 acute heart events in younger women. Many doctors are not aware it exists.

item.title: Could U.S. Measles Cases Break a Record This Year? What to Know
item.content:encoded: Within the first 3 months of 2024, the U.S. surpassed the total number of measles cases recorded in all of 2023. Could the nation break a record this year? Here's what to know.

item.title: Emulsifiers Make Food Appetizing yet Bring Health Dangers
item.content:encoded: Emulsifiers don’t necessarily equal junk food. Such substances can be found in many foods that are often considered healthy, such as some low-fat Greek yogurts, trail mix bars, or oat milk.

item.title: Tylenol During Pregnancy Not Linked to Higher Risk of ADHD, Autism
item.content:encoded: New findings should bring comfort to pregnant people who need pain relief, given that full-dose aspirin and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs have been shown to pose serious risks to pregnant patients.

item.title: Have Health Questions? Ask S.A.R.A.H., an AI Health Assistant
item.content:encoded: S.A.R.A.H., which stands for Smart AI Resource Assistant for Health, uses Open AI’s GPT (generative pretrained transformer) large language model to answer a wide range of health questions.

item.title: How Your ‘Sleep Style’ Can Determine Your Long-Term Health
item.content:encoded: The way you sleep – or don’t -- can be surprisingly impactful. The type of sleeper you are may profoundly influence the roadmap your health takes for a decade or longer. Here's what to know.

item.title: Why Saying ‘Hello, Stranger’ Could Be Key to Better Health
item.content:encoded: We tend to keep to ourselves in public – but experts say chatting with acquaintances and bystanders could be good for our mood and physical health.

item.title: Collagen Supplements for Skin, Hair, and Nails: What to Know
item.content:encoded: Data on collagen supplements is more plentiful than in the past, though still murky. Collagen supplements appear to be safe to take and somewhat effective, depending on what problem you’re trying to solve, what type of supplement you take, and which ingredients are included. Here's what to know.

item.title: How My New Golf Hobby Made Me Healthier in Unexpected Ways
item.content:encoded: The “spillover effect” teaches us that doing one healthy thing can lead to a whole lot more – if you can stick with it and move past the bad shots.

item.title: How the Body Reacts to Grief, and What It Can Mean
item.content:encoded: Fatigue, headaches, stomach pain, and a higher risk of heart disease: Although these things may not make you think of grief at first, many people who have a significant loss get these and other physical symptoms.

item.title: How Therapy Can Help During Life-Changing Events Like COVID
item.content:encoded: Research shows that forms of talk therapy like cognitive-behavioral therapy or dialectical behavioral therapy helped people better cope with anxiety during COVID. Here's what to know and how it can help you today.

item.title: Looking for More ZZZs? Consistent Activity May Be the Key
item.content:encoded: Sleep eludes millions of people. Can consistent exercise help?

item.title: Lower-Income Americans at Higher Risk of Death From Excess Salt
item.content:encoded: Lower-income communities often have less access to fresh, healthy food, leaving convenience stores and fast food as the primary sources of food.

item.title: How WW, Noom Say They're Filling Obesity Medicine Gaps
item.content:encoded: While applauding the role that these behavior-based weight management programs play in a comprehensive approach, an academic weight loss doctor thinks the order is backward.

item.title: Which OTC Health Products Are Best? New Report Claims to Know
item.content:encoded: The number and variety of over-the-counter health products on the market — from cough syrups to anti-wrinkle creams — can be overwhelming. Which to choose and which to bypass? Which work best?

item.title: Melatonin: A Valuable Resource or Children's Health Risk?
item.content:encoded: For Courtney Stinson, ensuring her daughter's comfort is a constant battle against congenital myopathy. The 9-year-old relies on a ventilator to breathe, has multiple respiratory treatments daily, and is under the constant care of rotating skilled caregivers. Last year alone, she had 36 doctor appointments.

item.title: Pandemic and Costs Limited Use of Shingles Vaccine
item.content:encoded: Only about 30% of adults eligible for Shingrix have gotten it, according to a 2022 report by the Government Accountability Office.

item.title: Which NSAID Is Right for You? Here's What to Know
item.content:encoded: Popular over-the-counter pain and inflammation drugs have been a revelation for people with pain, swelling, or even just run-of-the mill headaches. But these drugs, known as NSAIDs, which include Advil, Motrin, and others, are not all the same and come with some serious health risks if overused. Here’s how to make heads or tails of these commonly used drugs.

item.title: This Mutation Likely Saved a Colon Cancer Patient's Life
item.content:encoded: His tumor had a specific genetic makeup known as mismatch repair-deficient, present in 5% to 10% of all rectal cancer patients, meaning he might qualify for a cutting-edge immunotherapy.

item.title: Doctors Wary of Young Adults Using Ozempic for Bikini Season
item.content:encoded: With summer months approaching – and pressures that come with showing more skin – more and more young adults are looking to GLP-1 medications, like Ozempic, to get prepped for “swimsuit season.” But experts say there are critical things to consider before reaching for such medications, particularly for those struggling with body image issues.

item.title: Olivia Munn’s Breast Cancer: A Wake-Up Call for Women
item.content:encoded: Her doctor did an individual risk assessment, finding Munn’s lifetime risk was 37%, considered very high, and referred her to more extensive testing, which detected cancer in both breasts.

item.title: Why Immersion in Very Cold or Hot Water Can Be So Healthy
item.content:encoded: Cold plunges, hot tubs, face dunking – trendy water activities may be very good for you. We ask experts why.

item.title: How Exercise Can Help Ease Osteoarthritis Joint Pain
item.content:encoded: It may sound counterintuitive at first – suggesting that people with joint pain exercise and move more in general. But exercise can help ease osteoarthritis pain and improve mobility. Here's what to know.

item.title: At-Home Medical Tests: Are They Right for You?
item.content:encoded: At-home medical diagnostic testing has exploded in recent years. Here's what to know.

item.title: Just Breathe: Mindfulness Can Beat Tech Stress at Work
item.content:encoded: Preventing that burned out feeling is possible, experts say, by practicing mindfulness — an age-old approach focused on being aware of your feelings in the moment, without judgment or interpretation.

item.title: What Are Vaginal Gummies? Debunking the Latest Health Craze
item.content:encoded: Vaginal health gummies are all the rage for their supposed ability to get your vagina in optimal shape by improving its pH balance, taste, odor, and freshness. But experts say the vagina is naturally self-cleaning.

item.title: Is the Faith in Aspirin to Prevent Cardiac Events Warranted?
item.content:encoded: There’s a disconnect between the millions of people who take aspirin to ward off cardiovascular events and what the evidence shows.

item.title: Can You Really Lose Weight With Two Workouts a Week?
item.content:encoded: Understand how hard, long, and often you need to work out to actually make exercise work for weight loss.

item.title: Thunderstorm Asthma Could Strike More Often With Climate Change
item.content:encoded: Thunderstorm asthma can strike with little warning, leaving people with the symptoms of an asthma attack during or after the dark clouds pass. Here's what to know.

item.title: Xolair a New Weapon Against Food Allergies, but Questions Remain
item.content:encoded: An old drug offers new tricks for people with multiple food allergies, but costs and access issues could limit its use.

item.title: Mindful Eating Aims to Change Your Relationship With Food
item.content:encoded: You may be familiar with the basic steps: Slow down, notice what you’re eating, and enjoy your food. But mindful eating can be more nuanced, and if done with intention over time, it can change your relationship with food and benefit your health, experts say.

item.title: Stress May Lead to Metabolic Syndrome. Here's How to Overcome It
item.content:encoded: Stress management can help reduce the risk of metabolic syndrome, as well as harmful disease outcomes if you already have the condition.

item.title: Forever Chemicals Are Everywhere, But You Can Lower Your Risk
item.content:encoded: You can’t avoid the toxic chemicals that are infused into everyday living. But you can lessen some exposure.

item.title: Are There Exercises That Benefit Women More Than Men?
item.content:encoded: Weight training should be an essential part of anyone’s exercise regimen. But it’s especially important for women to incorporate weight training into their routines.

item.title: Do Patients Know When AI Is Assisting in Health Care?
item.content:encoded: When you message your health care provider about an appointment, a prescription refill, or to answer a question, is artificial intelligence or a person actually answering? In some cases, it’s hard to tell.

item.title: CDC Could Cut COVID Isolation Time: What It Could Mean
item.content:encoded: The agency appears to be walking a fine line between reducing COVID transmission, including the JN.1 variant, and the reality that many people struggle to forgo work or school for days at a time.

item.title: Beyond the Shots: Focusing on Gut Health Can Aid Weight Loss
item.content:encoded: It might not produce results as dramatic as regular injections, but you can get everything you need in a grocery store, for far less money -- and this approach has the potential to improve your health in numerous ways.

item.title: Elaborate Skin Care Routines Can Cause Teens More Harm Than Good
item.content:encoded: Experts say skin care is important, but teens are using too many products.

item.title: For Many, Stigma of Hearing Loss Brings Trouble; Here's What May Help
item.content:encoded: Experts say that resistance to treatment is deeply rooted in stigma. We’re more likely to ignore hearing loss because of its connection with old age and the clunky hearing aids we remember our grandparents wearing in our youth.

item.title: Automated External Defibrillators Save Lives, If You Use Them
item.content:encoded: All airports in the U.S. – and other public places where large groups tend to gather – are required by law to have AEDs. They are often red and kept in a white metal box attached to a wall.

item.title: Women Get More Health Benefits From Exercise Than Men
item.content:encoded: Women who spend the same amount of time on a treadmill, playing pickleball or just taking a brisk walk derive more lifesaving benefits from the exercise than men, according to a large new study

item.title: Fuel Your Body With Color: A New Guide to Healthy Eating
item.content:encoded: Turns out the pot of gold at the end of the (food) rainbow is health.

item.title: Your Keyboard May Contain More Bacteria Than Your Toilet Seat
item.content:encoded: Did you know that your keyboard may contain more bacteria than your toilet seat? Here's what to know about keyboard hygiene in the digital age.
